item.title: Like to bike? Your knees will thank you and you may live longer, too
item.description: New research shows lifelong bikers have healthier knees, less pain and a longer lifespan, compared to people who've never biked. This adds to the evidence that cycling promotes healthy aging.

item.description: The Trump's Trials team breaks down why prosecutors have a timeline problem, what Michael Cohen's testimony so far has shown, and why it may all come down to a question of sex and privacy in the end.

item.title: She was a single mom, alone at hospital with her son. Then a familiar face appeared
item.description: In 2006, Patricia Nieshoff's three-year-old son had a seizure. She was a single mother, with no one to accompany her to the hospital. But an hour into her hospital stay, a familiar face appeared.

item.title: When sea otters lose their favorite foods, they can use tools to go after new ones
item.description: Some otters rely on tools to bust open hard-shelled prey items like snails, and a new study suggests this tool use is helping them to survive as their favorite, easier-to-eat foods disappear.

item.title: Rwanda is transforming and growing — but at what cost?
item.description: Rwanda's post-genocide transformation has been remarkable, but uneven. And it prompts many questions, including: what type of leader is needed to help a country grow and heal?

item.title: Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi, a hard-liner who crushed dissent, dies at 63
item.description: Iran's ultraconservative president, killed in a helicopter crash, oversaw a crackdown on women's protests and was linked to extrajudicial killings in the 1980s.

item.title: Sperm whale families talk a lot. Researchers are trying to decode what they're saying
item.description:
Scientists are testing the limits of artificial intelligence when it comes to language learning. One recent challenge? Learning ... whale! Researchers are using machine learning to analyze and decode whale sounds — and it's just as complicated as it seems.

item.description: Taiwan's new President Lai Ching-te in his inauguration speech has urged China to stop its military intimidation against the self-governed island Beijing claims as its own territory.

item.title: U.S. troops and equipment will leave Niger by mid-September, the Pentagon says
item.description: Niger's decision to kick out American forces dealt a blow to U.S. military operations in the Sahel. U.S. troops and some gear already have begun leaving the country.
